recuperaci√≥n-muscular.content:
After an intense workout, muscles need to recover, and proper nutrition is key to this process. Even if you train well, if you don‚Äôt provide your body with the necessary ‚Äúmaterials,‚Äù progress may slow down. In this article, we‚Äôll tell you what foods to include in your diet to optimize muscle recovery.

üîß What Happens to Muscles After Training?
When you train, especially with weights or high-intensity exercises, micro-tears occur in the muscle fibers. This is a natural part of the growth process. Then, the body needs to ‚Äúrepair‚Äù these tissues, and during this repair, muscles become stronger and more resistant. To achieve this, the body needs:

- **Proteins** ‚Äì for muscle repair and growth;
- **Carbohydrates** ‚Äì to replenish muscle glycogen;
- **Water and electrolytes** ‚Äì to restore hydration balance.

ü•© **TOP 7 Foods for Muscle Recovery**
1. **Eggs** #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1586802990181-a5771596eaea?q=80&w=2070&auto=format&fit=crop&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxwaG90by1wYWdlfHx8fGVufDB8fHx8fA%3D%3D  "Image of muscle recovery"
 A high-quality source of protein. The yolk contains vitamins D and B12, which are important for energy metabolism and protein synthesis.
 #image: https://images.pexels.com/photos/5769384/pexels-photo-5769384.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1200 "Image of muscle recovery"
2. **Chicken or Turkey Breast**
   Rich in protein and low in fat. Ideal after strength training.
3. **Quinoa** #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1586201375799-47cd24c3f595?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MXx8UXVpbm9hfGVufDB8fDB8fHwy "Image of muscle recovery"
   A whole grain with all essential amino acids, plus fiber and complex carbohydrates.
4.  #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1587132137056-bfbf0166836e?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8Mnx8YmFuYW5hfGVufDB8fDB8fHwy "Image of muscle recovery" **Bananas**
   A source of fast carbohydrates and potassium, which helps prevent muscle cramps.
5.  #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1562114808-b4b33cf60f4f?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8OXx8WW9ndXIlMjBncmllZ298ZW58MHx8MHx8fDI%3D "Image of muscle recovery"
**Greek Yogurt**
   Contains both fast and slow-absorbing proteins, and also carbohydrates. Perfect as a post-workout snack.
 #image: https://images.pexels.com/photos/3682192/pexels-photo-3682192.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1200 "Image of muscle recovery" **Chia or Flax Seeds**
   Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which reduce inflammation and accelerate recovery.
 #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1639904822664-fb88a675420e?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MTN8fHNtb290aGllJTIwcmVkfGVufDB8MHwwfHx8Mg%3D%3D "Image of muscle recovery"
 **Berry Smoothie**
   The antioxidants from fruits like blueberries or raspberries help combat oxidative stress. Add plant-based or dairy protein for a complete smoothie.

üïí **When and How Much to Eat After Training?**
The best time to eat is between 30 and 60 minutes after training. During this period, the body absorbs nutrients more effectively.

**Examples of Post-Workout Meals:**

- Chicken breast + quinoa + steamed vegetables
- Greek yogurt + banana + walnuts
- Protein shake with oats and berries

üíß **Don't Forget to Hydrate**
During exercise, water and electrolytes are lost. Hydrate well with water, and if it was an intense session, you can add a pinch of sea salt or drink coconut water as a natural isotonic.

‚úÖ **Conclusion**
A good recovery doesn‚Äôt start with rest, but with what you put on your plate. Add proteins, complex carbohydrates, and healthy fats to your diet, and you‚Äôll see how your body responds better to training.

errores-alimentacion-entrenamiento.title: ü•¶ 5 Nutrition Mistakes That Slow Down Your Training Progress
errores-alimentacion-entrenamiento.content:
Many people train with discipline, but don't see the results they expect. What‚Äôs the cause? Often, it‚Äôs in their eating habits. Here are 5 common mistakes that may be slowing down your progress:

‚ùå **1. Skipping Post-Workout Meals**
#image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1539137071648-943c78fcbc84?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8Mnx8UG9zdCUyMHdvcmtvdXQlMjBtZWFsfGVufDB8fDB8fHww "Post-workout meal"
Your body needs ‚Äúfuel‚Äù to recover. Without nutrients, muscles won‚Äôt repair or grow. Make sure to eat something with protein and carbohydrates within 30‚Äì60 minutes after exercise.

‚ùå **2. Lack of Protein in the Diet**
Protein is crucial for recovery and muscle development. If you don‚Äôt consume enough, you‚Äôre training in vain. Include protein sources in every meal of the day.

‚ùå **3. Eating Only ‚ÄúHealthy‚Äù Foods Without Controlling Portions**
#image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1687184412163-09d005f5caa2?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MTZ8fEhlYWx0aHklMjBhbmQlMjBjYWxvcmljJTIwZm9vZHN8ZW58MHx8MHx8fDA%3D "Healthy and high-calorie foods"
Foods like avocado, nuts, or honey are healthy but also very high in calories. If you don't control portions, it‚Äôs easy to overeat, especially if your goal is to lose weight.

‚ùå **4. Not Drinking Enough Water**
#image: https://plus.unsplash.com/premium_photo-1729043730133-2d1d1a22760d?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MXx8SW1wb3J0YW5jZSUyMG9mJTIwd2F0ZXJ8ZW58MHx8MHx8fDA%3D "Importance of water"
Even slight dehydration affects your physical and mental performance. Drink water throughout the day, especially before and after training.

‚ùå **5. Too Little Fiber and Vegetables**
#image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597362925123-77861d3fbac7?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8OHx8SGVhbHRoeSUyMGFuZCUyMGNhbG9yaWMlMjBmb29kc3xlbnwwfHwwfHx8MA%3D%3D "Vegetables and fiber for recovery"
Without vitamins, minerals, and fiber, recovery will be slower. Vegetables help the digestive system, the immune system, and keep you balanced.

üîÅ **Conclusion:**
Training is only half the journey. The other half is conscious, balanced nutrition. Fix these mistakes and you'll see results much faster.

comida-pre-entrenamiento.title: ü•ó What to Eat Before Training: Key Foods for Energy and Endurance
comida-pre-entrenamiento.content:
What you eat before training has a huge impact on your energy, focus, and endurance. Exercising on an empty stomach or being too full isn‚Äôt ideal.

üïí **When to Eat?**
Ideally, eat between 1 and 2 hours before training. This way, your body has time to digest and make use of the nutrients.

‚úÖ **Ideal Foods Before Exercise:**

üçå **1. Banana**
Rich in fast carbohydrates and potassium, it gives you energy without feeling heavy.

üçû **2. Whole grain bread with nut butter**
Complex carbohydrates give sustained energy, and healthy fats feed your brain and muscles.

ü•£ **3. Yogurt with fruits** #image: https://plus.unsplash.com/premium_photo-1713719216015-00a348bc4526?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MXx8WW9ndXIlMjBjb24lMjBmcnV0YXMlMjBwcmUlMjBlbnRyZW5vfGVufDB8fDB8fHww "Pre-workout yogurt with fruits"
A light combination of protein and natural sugar to activate you.

üçö **4. Rice with vegetables and tofu or chicken** #image: https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1587995631109-2a8588e991da?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8M3x8QXJyb3olMjBjb24lMjB2ZWdldGFsZXNlMjB5JTIwcHJvdGUlQzMlQURuYXN8ZW58MHx8MHx8fDA%3D "Rice with vegetables and proteins"
Ideal if you train with high intensity. Consume 1.5‚Äì2 hours before.

üçµ **5. Green tea or lemon water** #image: https://plus.unsplash.com/premium_photo-1661540754348-50ae254e4a3b?w=600&auto=format&fit=crop&q=60&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxzZWFyY2h8MXx8VCVDMyVBOSUyMHZlcmRlJTIwbyUyMGFndWElMjBjb24lMjBsaW0lQzMlQjNuJTIwcHJlJTIwZW50cmVub3xlbnwwfDJ8MHx8fDA%3D "Green tea or lemon water pre-workout"
Hydrates and activates without filling the stomach.

üìå **Avoid Before Training:**
- Very fatty meals (slow to digest)
- Sweets or simple sugars (give quick energy but then drop)
- Skipping meals (can cause weakness or dizziness)

üí™ **Conclusion:**
Eating properly before training helps you perform better, avoid injuries, and stay focused. Find the combination that works best for you and enjoy the journey!
